claim_reports.claim_text: Climate change is due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that climate change is due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming that human emissions of CO2, methane, and nitrous oxide significantly enhance the greenhouse effect and contribute to global warming.

supports.title: Are humans causing or contributing to global warming? - Climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human activities are significantly increasing greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere, which enhances the greenhouse effect and contributes to global warming. It specifically states that the elevated CO2 levels are a direct result of human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels.
supports.snippet: Yes, by increasing the abundance of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, human activities are amplifying Earth's natural greenhouse effect.

supports.title: The Causes of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that climate change is due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity, detailing how human emissions of carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide have significantly increased since the Industrial Revolution, contributing to global warming.
supports.snippet: Human Activity Is the Cause of Increased Greenhouse Gas Concentrations. Over the last century, burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil has ...

supports.title: What Causes Climate Change? Human and Natural Causes - NRDC
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that climate change is due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity, detailing how human emissions of carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide have significantly altered Earth's energy balance and contributed to global warming.
supports.snippet: Human-driven causes of climate change: Transportation, Electricity generation, Industry & manufacturing, Agriculture, Oil & gas development, Buildings, ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The last years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that the last years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming that the past decade, particularly from 2015 to 2024, has recorded the highest temperatures since 1880.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the last decade has seen the warmest years since modern record-keeping began in 1880, with the past nine years being the warmest on record according to NASA's temperature analysis.
supports.snippet: The ten warmest years in the 175-year record have all occurred during the last decade (2015–2024).

supports.title: World of Change: Global Temperatures - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the past nine years have been the warmest years since modern recordkeeping began in 1880, supporting the claim about recent temperature trends.

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the last decade, specifically from 2015 to 2024, has been the warmest years on record since modern record-keeping began in 1880, with a significant increase in global temperatures attributed to human activities.
supports.snippet: WMO confirms 2024 as warmest year on record at about 1.55°C above pre-industrial level · The past ten years 2015-2024 are the ten warmest years ...

supports.title: Earth's 10 Hottest Years on Record Are the Last 10
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the last decade has been the warmest on record since modern record-keeping began in 1880, with the past nine years being the warmest years recorded.
supports.snippet: 2024 was the single warmest year on record, surpassing even 2023's wide lead over other recent years.

supports.title: Temperatures Rising: NASA Confirms 2024 Warmest Year on Record
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that 2024 is the warmest year on record since modern record-keeping began in 1880, and that the past decade has been the warmest overall, supporting the claim.

claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that the planet's climate is changing, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming significant increases in global average surface temperatures, including 2023 being the warmest year on record. Key sources include the Climate.gov report and NASA's analysis, both highlighting the role of human activity in driving these changes.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the planet's climate is indeed changing, as demonstrated by the significant rise in global average surface temperatures, which have increased by approximately 2°F since the pre-industrial era, and the accelerated warming rate observed in recent decades.
supports.snippet: Earth's temperature has risen by an average of 0.11° Fahrenheit (0.06° Celsius) per decade since 1850, or about 2° F in total.

supports.title: Monthly Climate Reports | Global Climate Report | Annual 2023
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that 2023 was the warmest year on record, with significant increases in global temperatures and numerous monthly records being set, supporting the claim that the planet's climate is changing.
supports.snippet: The year 2023 had the highest global mean surface temperature in the record, helped by the warm El Niño SST conditions over the last two-thirds of the year.

supports.snippet: Recent years have seen record-breaking temperatures and heat waves globally. Data show 2023 was the warmest year since global records began ...

supports.title: NASA Analysis Confirms 2023 as Warmest Year on Record
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the planet's climate is changing, as indicated by the record-high average surface temperatures in 2023 and the acknowledgment of a climate crisis by NASA officials. The analysis highlights the significant warming trend driven by human activity, particularly fossil fuel emissions, and the resulting impacts such as extreme heat and rising sea levels.
supports.snippet: Earth's average surface temperature in 2023 was the warmest on record, according to an analysis by NASA. Global temperatures last year were ...

supports.title: Why record 2023 warming matters even if you don't cover climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the planet's climate is indeed changing, as demonstrated by the record high temperatures in recent years and the significant increase in global average surface temperature since the pre-industrial era, primarily due to human-produced greenhouse gases.
supports.snippet: The research says on why 2023 was a record warm year and how climate predictions affect a range of news beats, from agriculture to aviation.

claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that sea levels are rising, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming an increase of approximately 3.3 mm per year and projections of a rise of 50 cm by 2100 due to climate change. Notable sources include NASA analyses and reports indicating significant acceleration in sea level rise.

supports.title: Can't 'See' Sea Level Rise? You're Looking in the Wrong Place
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that sea levels are rising, with current rates estimated at about 3.3 millimeters per year and projections indicating a rise of 50 cm by 2100 due to climate change. This aligns with the claim that sea levels are indeed rising.

supports.title: NASA Analysis Sees Spike in 2023 Global Sea Level Due to El Niño
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that global sea levels are rising, with a reported increase of about 0.3 inches from 2022 to 2023, attributed to climate change and El Niño effects. Additionally, long-term data shows a total rise of approximately 4 inches since 1993, indicating an accelerating trend in sea level rise.
supports.snippet: Global average sea level rose by about 0.3 inches (0.76 centimeters) from 2022 to 2023, a relatively large jump due mostly to a warming climate ...

supports.title: Why is Global Sea Level Rising? - Earth.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that sea levels are rising due to climate change, with current levels having risen between 10 and 25 cm over the last century and projections indicating a rise of 50 cm by 2100. This is attributed to global warming, which causes ocean warming and the melting of ice sheets and glaciers.
supports.snippet: Global sea level rise is mainly driven by climate change. Global warming from human activities leads to ocean warming and melting ice sheets and glaciers.

supports.title: Sea level rise: Everything you need to know
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that global sea levels are rising, having increased by about 10 cm since 1993, with an accelerating rate of rise attributed to climate change and phenomena like El Niño. This trend is supported by over 30 years of satellite observations and analysis from NASA.
supports.snippet: Global sea levels have already risen by over 10cm between 1993 and 2024, according to NASA, which says sea levels have been rising at ...

supports.title: The rate of global sea level rise doubled during the past three decades
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that global sea levels are indeed rising, with data showing an increase from approximately 2.1 mm/year in 1993 to about 4.5 mm/year in 2023, indicating a significant acceleration in the rate of sea level rise over the past three decades.
supports.snippet: The rate of global mean sea level rise over those three decades has increased from ~2.1 mm/year in 1993 to ~4.5 mm/year in 2023.

supports.title: These Photographs Show How the Rising Sea Connects Us All
supports.evidence_summary: The article provides substantial evidence that sea levels are rising, citing the rapid melting of Greenland's ice sheet as a primary driver and detailing the acceleration of sea level rise rates over recent decades. It also references predictions from the IPCC regarding future sea level increases, confirming the claim.
supports.snippet: The rapid melting of Greenland's ice sheet, the second-largest body of ice on earth after Antarctica, is the main driver of sea level rise ...

claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and NOAA, confirm that climate change is leading to an increase in the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events such as heatwaves, heavy rainfall, and wildfires.

supports.title: Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that extreme weather events, including heatwaves, heavy rainfall, and wildfires, are increasing in frequency and intensity due to climate change. It highlights that anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions and changes in land use are altering the global energy balance, leading to more extreme events.
supports.snippet: The US sustained 403 weather and climate disasters from 1980–2024 where overall damages/costs reached or exceeded $1 billion (including CPI adjustment to 2024).

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, including heatwaves, heavy rainfall, and wildfires, confirming the claim about the rise in such events.

supports.snippet: Rising global temperatures mean extreme weather events are becoming more common and more intense.

claim_reports.claim_text: We develop computer models to understand future climate change.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that computer models are developed to understand future climate change, as multiple high-reliability sources explain how climate models simulate and project future climate scenarios based on various factors.

supports.title: Climate Models
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that scientists use computer models, referred to as climate models, to simulate and understand how various factors influence climate change over time. These models allow for predictions about future climate scenarios based on different variables.
supports.snippet: Climate models are computer programs that simulate weather patterns over time. By running these simulations, climate models can estimate the Earth's average ...

supports.title: What Are Climate Models? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that scientists use computer models to simulate and understand how various factors influence Earth's climate, which supports the claim that computer models are developed to understand future climate change.
supports.snippet: In a climate model, a scientist can change the temperature of the oceans safely inside a computer. The model then figures how lots of other ...

supports.title: Basics of Global Climate Models
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that climate models, which are complex computer programs, are developed to project how the Earth's climate may change in the future based on various inputs and interactions. These models help scientists understand the potential impacts of different scenarios, including increased greenhouse gas emissions, on future climate conditions.
supports.snippet: Global climate models are computer programs that consist of several hundred thousand lines of code. They calculate the interactions between the ocean, ...

supports.title: Climate Models | NOAA Climate.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that climate models are developed to simulate and project future climate conditions based on various physical processes and inputs, confirming the claim that computer models are used to understand future climate change.
supports.snippet: Climate models are based on well-documented physical processes to simulate the transfer of energy and materials through the climate system.

supports.title: High-resolution climate model forecasts a wet, turbulent future
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence describes how climate models, including General Circulation Models, are developed to project future climate conditions based on various inputs and interactions within the Earth's systems. It emphasizes that these models help understand how different scenarios, such as increased greenhouse gas emissions, may affect future climate.
supports.snippet: For all their usefulness in forecasting global warming, climate models tend to paint the future in the broad strokes of an Impressionist artist.

claim_reports.claim_text: Technologies are being developed to limit future warming or respond to current warming.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources indicate that various technologies, including AI and blockchain, are being developed to address climate change and limit future warming. These technologies contribute to carbon trading, renewable energy, and overall climate adaptation efforts.

supports.title: 6 technologies to help the world adapt to climate change
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses various emerging technologies, such as blockchain and AI, that are being developed and utilized to address climate change and limit future warming. These technologies are being leveraged for carbon trading, renewable energy trading, and improving supply chain transparency, all of which contribute to climate adaptation and mitigation efforts.
supports.snippet: AI, drones, Earth observation, advanced computing, IoT and virtual and augmented reality are vital for climate adaptation. Here's why.

supports.title: Can tech save us from worst of climate change effects? Doesn't look ...
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses that new technology development has mitigated about 20 percent of the potential economic damage from climate change since 1960, indicating that technologies are indeed being developed to address climate change effects.
supports.snippet: New technology development has mitigated about 20 percent of the potential economic damage from climate change since 1960, the researchers estimate.

supports.title: From heat to high-tech: How innovation responds to climate change
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how new technologies are being developed in response to climate change, driven by public awareness, demand, and regulatory pressures, indicating a proactive approach to limit future warming and address current warming.
supports.snippet: We document that new technologies respond positively to climate change due to rising public awareness, shifting demand, and regulatory pressures. Introduction.

supports.title: 4 Emerging Technologies to Fight Climate Change | Earth.Org
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses various emerging technologies, such as blockchain and artificial intelligence, that are being developed and utilized to combat climate change and limit future warming. These technologies are being leveraged for carbon trading, renewable energy trading, and improving supply chain transparency, all of which contribute to environmental efforts.
supports.snippet: Blockchain, artificial intelligence, quantum computing, robotics are key emerging technologies in the fight against climate change.

supports.title: What would it take to scale critical climate technologies? - McKinsey
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the rapid advancement and deployment of various climate technologies aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, indicating that these technologies are being developed to limit future warming and respond to current climate challenges.
supports.snippet: Batteries · Carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) · Circular technologies · Energy storage · Engineered carbon removals · Heat pumps ...

transcript_data.text: Why does climate change matter? NASA We Asked a NASA Scientist. Well, it's happening. We look at the Earth from space and we measure it on the ground. And what we see is that the planet's climate is changing. The last years have been the warmest since modern record-keeping began. It's serious. Even a little change in temperature can have big effects. And we're seeing some of those effects now. Sea levels are rising. We're seeing more extreme events like heatwaves and heavy rainfall and wildfire. And we know that a lot of those effects are going to increase with more warming. These changes are impacting decisions that some people make every day, like a farmer thinking about what crops to grow or a homeowner thinking about flood risk. But there's hope. There are scientists at NASA and around the world that are researching this. We know more about our planet than we have ever before, and we learn more every day. So we know why climate is changing. We know that it's due to increasing greenhouse gases from human activity. We also have tools that can help us better understand and better prepare for future climate change. So we develop computer models that help us understand how much it might change in the future. And we're also developing technologies here at NASA and around the world that can help us limit future warming or respond to the warming that we're experiencing. So why does climate change matter? It's real. It's serious, and it's here. We Asked a NASA Scientist. NASA. A NASA 360 Production.
